article_title: Should the U.S. End the Ethanol Mandate?
article_text:
The Renewable Fuel Standard, otherwise known as the ethanol mandate, requires refiners to blend an increasing amount of biofuels into the U.S. gasoline supply each year.

Created in 2005, the standard was meant to help reduce carbon emissions as well as U.S. dependence on foreign oil. But critics question how much it has helped on either score. Some say corn ethanol, the fuel most commonly blended with gasoline under the standard,...

twitter.description: Robert Bryce says the ethanol mandate is bad for consumers and the environment. Margo T. Oge argues that the Renewable Fuel Standard is crucial to the development of a range of alternative fuels.
twitter.title: Should the U.S. End the Ethanol Mandate?

image.alt: Should the U.S. end the ethanol mandate?
